questions.text:
As the medical officer of a rural PHC, you are posted as a COVID 19 vaccination officer for your area. Which of the following items would you ask your team to take as part of a kit for your scheduled outreach vaccination session site?

 

  1. 3 swabs
  2. Adrenaline dose chart
  3. Certification format for expiry date of adrenaline
  4. 2 syringes with 14G or 16G needle
  5. 40 unit insulin needle with a fixed needle
  6. Inj. hydrocortisone
questions.solution:
An anaphylaxis kit should be carried to the outreach vaccination session site. The correct answer is 1, 2, 3. AEFI (Adverse Event Following Immunization) kit is made available in the fixed vaccination session site located at health facilities - PHC, CHC, Subdistrict, District hospitals, private health facility, and other designated AEFI management centers

The following components should be part of the anaphylaxis kit to be taken to the outreach vaccination session site

  • Job aid for recognizing anaphylaxis
  • Dose chart for adrenaline as per age
  • 1 mL ampoule of adrenaline (1:1000 aqueous solution) - 3 nos.
  • Tuberculin syringes (1 mL) or insulin syringe (of 40units, without fixed needle) – 3 nos.
  • 24G/25G needles (1 inch) – 3 nos.
  • Swabs – 3 nos.
  • Certification by Medical Officer for expiry dates of contents

Updated contact information of DIO(District Immunisation Officer), Medical Officer(s) of PHC/CHC, referral center, and local ambulance services should be readily available with the  vaccinator and supervisor 

 

In addition to the contents of the Anaphylaxis kit, AEFI has

  • Inj. hydrocortisone
  • Ringer lactate/Normal saline (1)
  • 5 % dextrose (1)
  • IV cannula/scalp vein set (2)
  • IV drip set (1)
  • Disposable syringe – 5 ml with 24 / 25G IM needle -3 sets
  • Adhesive tape

The distinction between the anaphylaxis kit meant for use at the outreach vaccination session site, and the AEFI kit, meant for use in the fixed vaccination session site is practical and clinically relevant. Knowledge of the resources available at each level is a necessity for timely referral whenever necessary.

questions.text: All of the following stimulate the release of the hormone that is deficient in patients with central diabetes insipidus except ________.
questions.solution:
Vasopressin is the hormone that is deficient in patients with central diabetes insipidus. All of the following stimulate vasopressin release except alcohol, which decreases vasopressin secretion.

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a condition in which there is the absence of or poor response to anti-diuretic hormone (ADH). This results in reduced permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to water. This furthermore leads the kidneys to excrete large amounts of dilute urine that clinically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia. 

DI can be:

  • Central DI - due to vasopressin deficiency or
  • Nephrogenic DI - due to failure of kidneys to repond to ADH

  • Infiltrative:

    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

questions.text:
Which of the following statement regarding the spaces of the hand are true?

1 - Infection of the thumb spreads to the radial bursa
2 - Ulnar bursa is drained with an incision over the radial margin of the hypothenar eminence
3 - Infection from the index finger spreads into mid palmar space
4 - Midpalmar space is better drained with an incision over the dorsum
5 - Infection of the ulnar space results in an 'hourglass swelling'
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2 and 5 are true

The following statements are true regarding the spaces of the hand - 

1 - Infection of the thumb spreads to the radial bursa
2 - Ulnar bursa is drained with an incision over the radial margin of the hypothenar eminence
3 - Infection from the index finger spreads into the thenar space not into the mid palmar space
4 - Midpalmar space is drained with an incision over medial 2 web spaces, not the dorsum
5 - Infection of the ulnar space results in an 'hourglass swelling'(Because of one swelling in the hand and one in the forearm)

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant with sickle cell disease is being evaluated in the emergency room for lethargy. The child has not been playful and has had a decreased appetite for the last three days. On examination, the temperature is 97F, blood pressure is 56/40 mm Hg. Skin turgor is severely reduced and the child appears septic. The child has a history of osteomyelitis for which treatment was initiated recently. The nurses are unsuccessful at establishing IV access as the veins are collapsed. Which of the following is correct about the next steps in management for this child?

choices.text: IO access can be established for fluid resuscitation in this patient
IV access is the only accepted modality of fluid resuscitation in a 9-month-old child
IO access is contraindicated in this patient based on her medical history
IO access has no associated complications and would be safer than IV access in this patient

questions.solution:
IO access can be established for fluid resuscitation in this patient. Sites of choice for intraosseous access include the proximal tibia, distal femur, the distal end of radius, or ulna.

Intraosseous access involves placing a catheter into the marrow venous plexus and administering, crystalloids, colloids, drugs, and blood which leads to rapid and reliable absorption into the systemic circulation. American Heart Association recommends the intraosseous IO route as an alternative to an intravenous route in order to deliver drugs and fluids, especially in children. This is because intraosseous access can easily be made in 30-60 seconds and thus provide emergency vascular access.

The fluids are administered under pressure because of the resistance to fluid flow from the IO catheter into the IO space. The disadvantage with this route is the risk of osteomyelitis, compartment syndrome, bone marrow, or fat embolism. IO access is superior to the endotracheal route for cardiac resuscitation.

 

Absolute contraindications
As the technique is primarily indicated in life-threatening emergencies, there are relatively few absolute contraindications to intraosseous (IO) infusions. If possible, IO cannulation should be avoided in the following patients:

  • A fractured bone or previously penetrated bone cannot be used because fluids will exit through the fracture or puncture site.
  • An extremity with vascular interruption, either from trauma or cutdown attempt, is not suitable for IO infusion because the fluid or drugs administered into the bone marrow will
    leak through the open blood vessel.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the given image is an anterior ethmoidal nerve block.

The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the roof of the nasal cavity. It is a branch of the nasociliary nerve which in turn is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve (V1). It is sometimes used in endonasal surgery.

Other options: 

Option A: In nasolacrimal duct syringing, the puncta of the nasolacrimal duct near the medial canthus of the eye is probed using a lacrimal cannula. The below image shows lacrimal syringing.

Option C: Infraorbital nerve block causes anesthesia in the distribution of infraorbital nerve which includes lower lid, cheek, side of nose, upper lip, and upper teeth. It is most commonly done for dental procedures.

Option D: Trephination of the frontal sinus is a surgical procedure done for the drainage of pus in acute frontal sinusitis. In this procedure, the incision is made on the floor of the frontal sinus.

questions.text: As part of the program based on NHM guidelines for the prevention and control of hemoglobinopathies in India, you are posted in a screening camp meant to screen for carriers of hemoglobinopathies. All of the following are test tube-based turbidity tests that you would use in the camp planned at a community setting except:
questions.solution:
NESTROFT Test, DCIP test, and Hemoglobin Solubility Test are used in the community setting to screen for carriers of hemoglobinopathies and are Test tube-based Turbidity tests. 

HPLC is not used in the community camp setting and is not a Test tube-based Turbidity test. HPLC stands for High-performance liquid chromatography. Hemoglobin HPLC is used for the diagnosis of thalassemia disease, variant Hemoglobin disease, thalassemia trait, and variant Hemoglobin traits like sickle cell trait.

Hemoglobin solubility test is used for the screening of hemoglobin S. It may be used for initial screening in older children and adults, especially for mass screening. But this test cannot distinguish between sickle cell trait (heterozygotes) and sickle cell disease (homozygotes). It is not recommended for infants under 6 months because the high proportion of fetal hemoglobin in relation to adult sickle cell hemoglobin in a newborn's blood may affect the results.

DCIP test (Di-Chlorophenol-IndoPhenol) is used for hemoglobin E screening. It is a simple screening test based on the oxidation of the exposed –SH group by DCIP at neutral pH. This leads to precipitation of the variant hemoglobin leading to a particulate cloudy solution or precipitated HbE at the bottom of the tube obervable by the naked eye.

NESTROFT (Naked Eye Single Tube Red-cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is a highly sensitive test used as a screening test for Beta thalassemia trait.

questions.text: A 78-year-old diabetic male patient presents with a week-long history of severe pain in and discharge from the right ear and pain in the jaw while chewing. Examination reveals exquisite tenderness, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and granulation tissue on the floor of the external auditory canal. Which of the following is the appropriate management for this condition?

choices.text: Continue topical therapy for one week
Intravenous anti-pseudomonas drugs along with ear toileting
Biopsy of granulation tissue and topical steroid therapy for one week

questions.solution:
The appropriate management for the given condition is initiating intravenous anti-pseudomonal drugs along with ear toileting. 

The given clinical scenario of an elderly diabetic developing severe pain, whitish discharge from the right ear associated with pain while chewing, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and the finding of granulation tissue in the inferior portion of the external auditory canal, is suggestive of malignant otitis externa. This is a life-threatening condition; the patient must be admitted and started on intravenous ciprofloxacin (anti-pseudomonal agents). 

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition seen in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs due to pseudomonal infection. It is an infective condition and not a malignant condition. It mimics diffuse otitis externa associated with excruciating pain, discharge, and granulations on the floor of EAC. Bony erosion aids in the spread of infection. Facial paralysis is common. Multiple cranial nerve palsies can occur when the infection spreads to the skull base and jugular foramen. The infection can spread anteriorly into the temporomandibular fossa. 

Diagnosis: Severe ear pain associated with granulation tissue in the external auditory canal in a diabetic patient should raise the suspicion of malignant otitis externa. CT scan helps in detecting bony erosions and demineralization of the bones. Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but cannot be used to monitor the disease as the test remains positive for a year or so.

Treatment: The treatment of malignant otitis external would include control of diabetes, ear toileting to remove the discharge, debris or granulation tissue, antibiotic therapy against Pseudomonas with fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins, beta-lactam antibiotics with/without aminoglycosides.

Other options:

Option B- Prolonged antibiotic treatment has replaced radical surgery and resections which were done previously for this condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with increased fatigue, low-grade fevers, and night sweats. Physical examination reveals several small, rubbery, mobile, non-tender supraclavicular lymph nodes. The lymph node biopsy findings are shown in the image below. Immunophenotyping shows CD15+, CD30+, and PAX5+. Activation of which of the following factors occurs in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the image showing Reed-Sternberg cells are suggestive of a diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. Activation of the transcription factor NF-κB is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

NF-κB may be activated by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV+ tumor cells express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1), a protein encoded by the EBV genome that transmits signals that upregulate NF-κB. Activation of NF-κB may occur in EBV tumors as a result of the acquired loss-of-function mutations in TNF alpha-induced protein 3 (TNFAIP3). (Option D)

Activation of NF-κB by EBV or other mechanisms rescues “crippled” germinal center B cells that cannot express Igs from apoptosis, eventually leading to the formation of Reed-Sternberg cells. TNF α, IL-10, and TGF beta are involved in cross-talk between Reed-Sternberg cells and other normal cells in classical forms of Hodgkin's lymphoma. (Option A and B)

Reed-Sternberg cell: It is a giant cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.

Clinical features of Hodgkin's lymphoma - Typical presentation involves lymphadenopathy/ mass with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Diagnosis - Requires microscopic findings and immunophenotyping findings to correlate. Microscopy of lymph nodes shows the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

A 2 year old child who still requires support for standing
A 2 year old child who is unable to walk alone

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain. He states that he has been having 4-5 non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. He denies any family history of colon cancer. A biopsy of the small bowel showed findings as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most commonly associated cancer?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with the biopsy image showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and lamina propria infiltrates, indicates a case of celiac disease. The most common celiac disease-associated cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.

Celiac disease/celiac sprue/gluten-sensitive enteropathy:

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy. It is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8. The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin (gluten-derived peptide). The gliadin peptide activates the epithelial cells to express IL-15, which in turn triggers activation and proliferation of CD8+ intraepithelial lymphocytes. This damages the epithelium and increases the passage of gliadin into the lamina propria, where gliadin is deamidated by the tissue transglutaminase (tTG), an intestinal enzyme. The deamidated gliadin is more immunogenic and is presented to helper T cells which mediate mucosal inflammation and worsen tissue damage.

Microscopic findings on biopsy of the proximal small intestine will show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes.

Clinically, patients with celiac disease present with malabsorption syndrome with diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, chronic refractory anemia, and marked unintentional weight loss. Some patients may also present with dermatitis herpetiformis characterized by herpes-like vesicles that are caused due to the deposition of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae.

Antiendomysial and anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are found in serological studies. Symptoms can be reversed by a gluten-free diet.

In refractory cases of celiac disease, patients should be started on oral steroids (prednisolone). After induction of clinical remission, azathioprine can be added.

The below image shows a patient with dermatitis herpetiformis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old G3P1L1A1 at 37 weeks of gestation presents to the ER with labor pains. Her past obstetric history includes a previous history of emergency cesarean section due to fetal distress and dilatation and curettage done for an unplanned pregnancy. Abdominal examination reveals a singleton live term pregnancy with adequate liquor and assuring fetal vitals. The estimated fetal weight by Johnson's formula is 3100 grams. Per vaginal examination revealed partially effaced cervix and fetus stationed at 0 stations. She is posted for TOLAC - Trial of labor after cesarean section. The first stage of labor was uneventful. She was given epidural analgesia for pain management. Suddenly, her vitals started deteriorating and she started complaining of dizziness and severe chest pain.  Her BP - 80/60 mm of Hg, RR - 20/ min, HR - 106/ min, SpO2 - 97% under room air. B/L chest is clear with NVBS. Abdominal examination reveals no scar tenderness. CTG showed a non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate pattern. The most likely diagnosis is ____________
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is uterine rupture.

Previous cesarean section and Dilatation and curettage are both potential risk factors for scar dehiscence and uterine rupture. Hypotension, tachycardia, dizziness, confusion, abdominal pain, scar site tenderness are all the signs of uterine rupture. In the given clinical picture, the use of epidural analgesia is likely to have contributed to the absence of scar site tenderness. Rarely, Hemoperitoneum can irritate the diaphragm and cause chest and shoulder tip pain. 

CTG in uterine rupture will show non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate which might progress to late decelerations and bradycardia. 

Differential diagnoses for uterine rupture:

  • Pre-eclampsia 
  • Eclampsia
  • Pulmonary embolism - amniotic fluid embolism / venous embolism
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Anaphylaxis to anesthesia
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy 

Management of uterine rupture:

  • confirm the fetal station and arrest of labor
  • Stabilize the patient's vitals
  • Immediate cesarean section should be performed, immediately/ as early as possible to avoid neurological or hypoxic sequelae in newborns.
  • Depending on the extent of rupture and vitals on the table decision of uterine suturing or hysterectomy or sub-total hysterectomy may be taken. 

 

Other options:

  1. Amniotic fluid embolism - can present with similar symptoms but oxygen saturation will be deteriorating to less than 95% and the respiratory rate will increase.
  2. Placental abruption - No history of hypertension and BP is not elevated
  3. Anaphylaxis to epidural analgesia - absent cutaneous and respiratory symptoms makes it a less likely possibility.

questions.text: During your community medicine postings, each student is assigned a family in the neighboring district for evaluating various social, economic, and health parameters. You were asked to grade the families according to the modified Kuppuswamy’s socioeconomic status scale. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this scale?

choices.text: Kuppuswamy scale does not include housing
This scale can be used for both rural and urban areas
There are 5 socio-economic classes according to this scale
Monthly income of the family is taken into consideration in this scale

questions.solution:
The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas and not in rural areas. 

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family 
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family 

Each of the components is assigned a score. It is then classified into socio-economic classes based on the total score as follows:

Socio-economic class Total Score
I Upper 26-29
II Upper-middle 16-25
III Lower-middle 11-15
IV Upper-lower 05-10
V Lower <5

Note:

  • Uday Pareek scale should be used for those in rural areas. 
  • BG Prasad scale can be used in both urban and rural areas.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

questions.text: While performing bone grafting, which of the following instruments would you use to elevate the periosteum?
questions.solution:
The instrument used in the elevation of the periosteum is a periosteal elevator shown in image A.

It is used to elevate the periosteum, as nerves and vessels are generally on this plane, and once elevated there is a safer plane for surgery.

Option B: The image shows a curette used for curetting a cavity in the bone or removing fibrous tissue from the ends of a fracture. It is used in the management of enchondroma, GCT, and osteomyelitis.

Option C: The image shows an osteotome. It has both sides beveled and is used for cutting bone in surgeries such as McMurray's osteotomy and corrective osteotomy. 

Option D: It shows a bone gouge, a concave-bladed chisel used for cutting round bone surfaces or making holes in the bone.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: A 72-year-old retired pilot presents to his neurologist, accompanied by his wife, with memory loss, headache, and fatigue. She says that there has been a significant change in his personality over the past few months. The patient’s history was significant for his having received a corneal transplant about 18 months ago. Blood investigations were normal. CT scans showed mild cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, but no mass lesions. However, the patient died while investigations were still being done. An autopsy revealed extensive changes in his cerebrum, cerebellum, and basal ganglia to a spongiform consistency, which were diagnostic of the disease-causing agent. Which of the following is false about his diagnosis?

choices.text: The corneal transplant is responsible for the infection
EEG would have shown sharp periodic biphasic waves
Similar disease can occur in goats and cows
It can be diagnosed by PCR on CSF

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) and the incorrect statement among the given options is option D- 'It can be diagnosed by PCR on CSF'. This is because CJD is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion. Prions are proteinaceous infectious agents that are devoid of nucleic acids. Therefore, they cannot be detected using nucleic acid amplification techniques such as PCR. 

The proteins that make up the prions (PrP) are present even normally in the cells. This normal form, PrPc, is in a predominantly α-helical configuration and is sensitive to proteases. However, the prions (infectious form) are in an abnormal β-pleated configuration and are called PrPSc. This pathological form is not degradable by proteases and converts the normal form- PrPc to the abnormal form- PrPSc. This abnormal protein gets deposited as plaques and degeneration of surrounding neuronal and glial tissue occurs characterized by intracellular vacuoles, leading to a characteristic spongiform encephalopathy. There is no associated inflammatory response to these agents. 

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  • Sporadic (sCJD): Most common;
  • Variant (vCJD): Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease), Kuru;
  • Familial (fCJD): These individuals carry a PrPc mutation and include Gerstmann-Sträussler- Scheinker syndrome and fatal familial insomnia;
  • Iatrogenic (iCJD): Maybe seen occurring after corneal transplantation, liver transplantation, use of contaminated neurosurgical instruments, use of cadaver-derived hormones, or stereotactic depth electrodes. 

Clinically, CJD presents with predominantly CNS manifestations with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus (startle myoclonus is common), ataxia, akinetic mutism, visual disturbances, and pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction. Insomnia, apathy, and other behavioral abnormalities may be seen. 

CSF is predominantly normal but may show a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. EEG may show periodic triphasic or multiphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes or spike-wave pattern. MRI on FLAIR sequencing and diffusion-weighted imaging will show increased intensity in the basal ganglia region and a characteristic 'cortical ribboning', in sporadic CJD. Diagnosis of CJD can be established on brain biopsy either by measuring PrPSc or by demonstrating the characteristic neuropathological features of spongiform encephalopathy.

Management is mainly supportive as the disease is usually fatal within a year of onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with symptoms of headache and blurred vision for the last few weeks. He also complains of tingling and numbness in his lower extremities. He has noticed occasional bleeding from his gums and diarrhea. The patient's past medical history indicates he is diabetic but not hypertensive. On examination, the patient is poorly nourished, vitals are within normal limits. Abdominal examination reveals mild hepatomegaly. Fundoscopy shows the presence of dilated, segmented,  tortuous veins, giving it a "sausage link" appearance and some retinal hemorrhages. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, prolonged bleeding time, and elevated total proteins. The clinical picture causes suspicion of macroglobulinemia. Flow cytometry shows sIgM+ CD5- CD10- CD19+ CD20+ CD23- immunophenotype in association with a nonparatrabecular pattern of infiltration on bone marrow biopsy. The most likely diagnosis is

choices.text: IgM monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance

questions.solution:
Flow cytometry shows sIgM+ CD5- CD10- CD19+ CD20+ CD23- immunophenotype in association with a nonparatrabecular pattern of infiltration in a patient with typical clinical manifestations is clinching of a diagnosis of Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia

The clinical vignette describes a patient likely to be diagnosed with Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia when subjected to serum protein electrophoresis. 

Clinical presentation:

  • Hyperviscosity syndrome
  • Neuropathy that predominantly affects the lower limbs
  • Fundoscopic abnormalities include dilated, segmented, tortuous veins, giving it a "sausage link" appearance. Other retinal lesions, including hemorrhages, exudates, and papilledema may be impressive, and central retinal vein thrombosis can occur.
  • Cryoglobulinemia
  • Kidney involvement
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms

Waldenström macroglobulinemia

  • Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a neoplasm of small lymphocytes and a variable number of IgM-secreting plasma cells.
  • It is a syndrome in which high levels of IgM lead to symptoms related to hyperviscosity of the blood.
  • It occurs in older adults.
  • It most commonly occurs in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.
  • ‘M’ or monoclonal spike is seen. (It is caused by IgM; in MM, it is caused by IgG.)
  • The absence of lytic lesions and serum calcium levels are normal.
  • Diffuse marrow infiltration by plasma cells, plasmacytoid lymphocytes, and lymphocytes (all from the same clone).
  • Cells do not form tumor masses or produce lytic lesions.
  • Lymphocytes commonly contain Dutcher bodies (intranuclear inclusions).
  • Bence–Jones proteins are found in 20–30%.

Hyperviscosity syndrome:

  • Normal relative serum viscosity ranges from 1.4 to 1.8 units. However, symptoms are not seen at <4 units. Hyperviscosity syndrome typically requires a viscosity >5 units.
  • Hyperviscosity in plasma cell dyscrasias is due to excess IgM paraprotein.
  • Symptomatic hyperviscosity is much more common in Waldenström's macroglobulinemia (10 to 30%) than it is in myeloma (2 to 6%).
  • Less frequently, it also occurs in multiple myeloma (with myeloma proteins IgA and IgG3 types) and connective tissue diseases.
  • Clinical features: Visual impairment, neurologic problems, bleeding, and cryoglobulinemia.

 

Other options:

  • In IgM monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance, anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms are usually absent with minimal or no lymphoplasmacytic infiltration of the bone marrow
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is CD5 positive, CD23 positive, and FMC7 negative
  • Mantle cell lymphoma is CD5 positive, CD23 negative.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman was admitted to the ICU with fever and hypotension. On the morning of admission, she had a fever, rigors, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. As the day progressed, she developed redness of her skin all over and became lethargic and ultimately quite difficult to arouse. Her BP was noted to be 70/50 mmHg, with a pulse of 140 bpm, and a temperature of 39.5°C. She is minimally responsive. Skin examination reveals generalized erythroderma but no signs of skin infection. Examination per vagina reveals a retained tampon that is immediately removed. You suspect staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome (TSS). Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?
  1. It is caused by a toxin that binds to the invariant region of the MHC
  2. Skin site infection is clinically apparent in most cases
  3. Blood cultures will likely return positive by 24–36 hours 
  4. Desquamation of the skin will occur within 1–2 days.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, only statement 1 is true.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) results from enterotoxins and toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) of Staphylococcus aureus that act as T-cell mitogens or superantigens. 

Normally, antigens are first processed within the cell, and peptides are then presented in the MHC class II groove, initiating a controlled T-cell response. TSST-1 is called a superantigen because they bind directly to the invariant region of MHC—outside the MHC class II groove (peptide-binding cleft), causing the T cells to be activated nonspecifically. They then bind T-cell receptors via the vβ chain and this binding results in drastic overexpansion of T-cell clones. This T-cell expansion causes a cytokine storm with the release of inflammatory mediators such as interferon-γ, IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α, and TNF-β, resulting in inflammatory response and shock.

Clinically, patients present with fever with a temperature of ≥38.9C ( ≥102F), hypotension with a systolic blood pressure of ≤90 mmHg, an erythematous rash with desquamation 1–2 weeks after onset (including the palms and soles), and multiorgan involvement including mucosal hyperemia, vomiting, diarrhea, myalgia, etcetera. 

Other statements-

Statement 2: In most cases of staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome, both menstrual and non-menstrual cases, a skin site of infection is not clinically apparent.

Statement 3: Toxic shock syndrome is mediated by toxin formation, therefore, the blood cultures are almost always negative.

Statement 4: Desquamation of the skin rash of TSS often occurs 1-2 weeks after the onset of the illness.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female is rushed into the ER after a drug overdose. Her father suffers from heart failure and she consumed one of his medications. Her medical history is unremarkable. The drug acts on the site marked with an 'X' in the image below. Which of the following is/are correct regarding the drug that this patient is likely to have ingested?
  1. The earliest side effects are nausea and vomiting
  2. Causes non-specific color vision
  3. Hypokalemia is associated with toxicity
  4. It causes hypomagnesemia
questions.solution:
The drug acting on the site marked with an 'X' in the image shown is digoxin. Options 1 and 3 are correct.

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used in the management of congestive cardiac failure and cardiac arrhythmias. In congestive cardiac failure, it is used to improve cardiac contractility by increasing intracellular calcium.

Gastrointestinal side effects include anorexia, nausea, and vomiting due to its effect on chemosensors in the area postrema (statement 1). Digoxin affects color vision specifically, causing, xanthopsia or yellow vision (statement 2). Hypokalemia is associated with an increased risk of early and delayed afterdepolarizations, and ectopic pacemaker activity, especially in the presence of digitalis. Digitalis toxicity causes hyperkalemia (statement 4). Factors predisposing to digoxin toxicity: 

  • Hypokalemia (more digoxin binds to the Na+/K+ ATPase) (statement 3)
  • Hypercalcemia (increases the risk of arrhythmia)
  • Hypomagnesemia (Mg++ is a co-factor for Na+/K+ ATPase)
  • Renal failure (for digoxin) 

Management of toxicity involves the use of atropine, K+ infusion, and antidigoxin immunotherapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male receiving treatments for depression elsewhere is brought by his elder brother. His elder brother states that he has not stepped out of his bed since morning and has not uttered a single word. He adds that despite repeated attempts of talking, the patient keeps staring at the wall. In the afternoon patient started spiking fever and lost control over his bowel and bladder and soiled the bed. On examination, his vitals are fluctuating and blood pressure is slightly on the higher end of the spectrum. A diagnosis of malignant catatonia is made. What is the first-line management of this patient?

choices.text: Carry out an EEG and administer phenytoin

questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis of this case is Malignant catatonia and is a psychiatric emergency with 25% mortality rate. The first line management for the patient is emergency ECT. 

Stupor is a common condition seen in catatonia, defined as a clinical syndrome of akinesis and mutism, but with relative preservation of consciousness. 

The patient is a known case of depression. Usually, stupor followed by mania and depression are classical of functional/psychiatric malignant catatonia. 

Other options:

  • Lorazepam is proven to be beneficial in all other cases of stupor and is generally preferred. If the patient does not measurably respond to a benzodiazepine within the first day or two, ECT should commence and the benzodiazepine should be discontinued. 
  • If we suspect organic stupor secondary to meningitis, encephalitis, Carbon monoxide posioning, we must perform an EEG and check for electrolyte abnormalities. The most common electrolyte abnormality causing this condition is periodic palsy due to potassium imbalance.
  • Amytal interview is generally undertaken to differentiate between organic and functional causes of stupor in doubtful conditions. 

Stupor can be due to a variety of organic and psychogenic causes.

Features Organic Stupor Psychogenic stupor
Previous illness present Mostly medical Mostly psychiatric
Course Longer Shorter, recovery usually within 7 days
Protective reflexes (Blepharospasm) Absent Present
Resistance to eye opening Absent Present
Doll' head eye phenomenon Present Absent, may even avoid examiner's gaze
Posturing Absent Present
Urinary incontinence Usually present  Absent
Amytal interview Low dose (100-150 mg) increases stupor and neurological signs High dose (300-400 mg) increases alertness, and then a mental state examination can be conducted.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old primigravida comes to the clinic at 31-weeks gestation with complaints of intolerable pruritus at night, particularly in her palms and soles. She also has right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and poor appetite. Her laboratory investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the appropriate management for her condition?
Liver Function Tests Values
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 4
Aspartate aminotransferase (U/L) 180
Alanine aminotransferase (U/L) 200
Alkaline phosphatase (U/L) 250
Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (U/L) 60
Albumin (g/dL) 3
Prothrombin time (s) 11

An infectious disease panel is negative.
questions.solution:
This patient at 31 weeks gestation with intolerable pruritus over her palms and soles at night, right upper quadrant pain, nausea, poor appetite, and abnormal liver function tests is likely to have intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. 

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is also known as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, icterus gravidarum, or cholestatic hepatosis. It occurs during the late 2nd and early 3rd trimesters. The etiology is not well understood but is thought to be due to a relation between the cholestatic properties of reproductive hormones in genetically susceptible women. 

It usually presents with intense pruritus after 30 weeks of gestation over the palms and soles and is worse at night. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, fatigue, right upper quadrant pain, dark urine, and pale stool. 

Hyperbilirubinemia results from retention of conjugated pigment, but total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 4 to 5 mg/dL. Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated and may occasionally reach levels up to 1000 mg/dL. Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated. Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Management:

  • Antihistamines and topical emollients 
  • Cholestyramine
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid

Disorder

 AST (SGOT) U/L Bilirubin (mg/dL)
Cholestasis of pregnancy Upto 200 usually but may be higher in certain cases 1–5
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy 200–800 4–10
Hepatitis 2000+ 5–20
